title: Ticket #7166: Schedd should materialize more than one job per transaction
description:
Currently the when the Schedd is materializing jobs, it use a transaction for each job. This means that we do a fsync for each job, which is slowing the Schedd down. Many times when the late materialization timer fires, it will actually add more than one job from a single cluster into the queue. This is especially true the first time the late materialization timer fires on a new cluster.

If the late materialization code used a single transaction for all of the jobs it added to the queue in a single cycle, this should greatly reduce the number of fsyncs.

Since late materialization adds no new information to the job, we can use NONDURABLE transactions to commit the job materialization. This will reduce fsyncs even more.

If a NONDURABLE materialized job should never be written to the job_queue.log, the worst think that would happen is that users might observe submit events being written to the job's log for jobs that are not yet present in the schedd immediately after it restarts. Those missing jobs would soon materialize again, and with the exact same job attributes (and a duplicate submit event in the job's log file)

In an abundance of caution, we will add a hidden knob to allow DURABLE transactions to be re-enabled. The knob will be called SCHEDD_NON_DURABLE_LATE_MATERIALIZE and it will default to true.

Code Review

  • What's the point of firstid and lastid? You don't use them and other potential users of TransactionWatcher may have no good value to pass to BeginOrContinue().
  • Add SCHEDD_NON_DURABLE_LATE_MATERIALIZE to the param table.
  • Comment at qmgmt.cpp:493: // returns bool if materialization of a single job It looks like the 'bool' should be 'true'.

Otherwise, the code looks good.

2019-Aug-09 13:35:30 by johnkn:
All changes will be to a job ad, so there will always be an id to pass to BeginOrContinue(). the point of tracking firstid and lastid is better error/logging messages.
